Probably one of the biggest struggles is getting our Asian community to understand that every time we bring an Asian film into mainstream theaters, we‚Äôre competing head-to-head with Hollywood films for screens. So as you can imagine, if theaters are given a choice to play a Hollywood film or an independent/Asian film, I think you can guess the outcome. üòÄ I‚Äôm very motivated to support our international and independent creative voices and 3388 Films and I consistently take lots of risks to try to make this happen on a frequent basis for our communities. The Last Wife will play in over 50 theaters across the U.S and Canada starting tomorrow, Friday Dec 8. I always ask myself: if we don‚Äôt support our communities, who will? Is it time for the international market to reign supreme over domestic? With no end in sight for the SAG-AFTRA/WGA strikes, professionals at Toronto International Film Festival believe that it is. Production has taken a halt (aside from productions who received interim agreements) across the USA and could continue this way well into next year. Several distributors are looking to use international English-speaking films to fill their 2024/2025 roster, leaving those in the USA who are bound to the SAG guidelines to step out of the light. Francesco Rutelli, president of the Italian national audiovisual association Anica, believes that ‚Äúif supply decreases with Hollywood on strike, we need to be ready with our products for the international market as well." I believe that the market will be able to fill the gaps with UK and Canadian films, but there are far too many American stars for this to suffice for much longer. This opens an intriguing conversation as to how the industry will look after the strikes end, and if the international market will continue in this direction when the USA is able to produce again. The African film industry has made significant strides in recent years, but there's still a long way to go. The lack of experimentation and risk-taking is stifling creativity and holding us back from producing films that truly resonate with global audiences. We need to challenge ourselves to tell more nuanced, complex, and visually stunning stories that showcase the depth and diversity of African experiences. The comfort zone is a seductive trap, and it's easy to get stuck in it. But complacency is the enemy of progress. By embracing new ideas, techniques, and collaborations, we can elevate the standard of African filmmaking and make a lasting impact on the global cinematic landscape. So, let's take a step back and assess our approach. Are we merely replicating the same formulas and styles, or are we pushing the envelope and exploring new frontiers? Are we prioritizing artistic expression over commercial success, or are we sacrificing creativity for the sake of box office returns? It's time to break free from the comfort zone and challenge the norm. Let's collaborate with international filmmakers, experiment with new genres and styles, and invest in innovative storytelling techniques. Let's create films that not only entertain but also educate, inspire, and challenge our audiences. The future of African cinema depends on our willingness to take risks and push the boundaries. So, let's do it. Let's challenge the status quo and create a new wave of African films that will be remembered for generations. #filmmaking #Africanfilms #Africanstories #Africancinema #Africanfilmindustry
